ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course covered how signals can be modeled, transformed, and represented in both the time and frequency domains. We also studied feedback models, and various ways of representing engineering systems.

We learned about discrete and continuous-time signals, linear systems, fourier series and transfroms, laplace transforms, z-transforms, and Simulink. We also learned analysis and control by using laplace transforms.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The lectures were very disorganized which made it hard to learn the material.

I think this course was tough to take virtually, and could have been improved with some more real world examples and demonstrations. The material was solid though, and I feel like I learned a lot. There was a lot of math, but the instruction and textbook did a good job explaining it.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: There wasn't a lot done outside of the lectures. They were all recorded so that students could watch them on their own time, which led to low class attendance, causing there to be less engagement.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Only if you want to get into the systems side of EE.
I wouldn't recommend it, but I know some people will have to take it.

This is a fairly rigorous course. For students really interested in electrical or systems engineering, the content is essential. However, it is certainly an easy STEM class that can be used to fulfill a science or math distributional requirement.
I would recommend this course to someone looking to increase their exposure to electrical engineering principles and increase their ability to work with signals.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: It was live virtual lectures that were recorded for students that wanted to see the recordings.
